pageContent:
Impacts of Managed Bees on 
Wild Pollinators 
ENTOM 2030 Guest Lecture 
Kaitlin Deutsch | 
McArt 
Lab | Cornell Entomology

Learning Objectives: Managed vs.Wild Pollinators 
      
  
 
 
 
 
    
  
   
       
     
     
•
 
Recognize the diversity of managed pollinators beyond honey bees. 
•
 
Identify ways in which managed bees may 
negatively influence wild pollinators. 
•
 
Explore strategies to mitigate negative 
impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators.

Part I
: Managed Pollinators Beyond the Honey Bee 
 
         
  
              
  
  
           
    
 
      
  
Throughout the world, many other insect species are managed for crop 
pollination services, not just the honey bee! 
~
100 unique insect taxa 
have been evaluated for their pollination 
services 
as managed pollinators

Part I
: Managed 
Pollinators Beyond the 
Honey Bee 
Bumble bees 
Hover flies 
Leafcutter bees 
Mason bees 
Stingless bees

Part I
: Managed Pollinators Beyond 
the Honey Bee 
Preference for native pollinators in regions 
where honey bees are non-native

Part I
: Managed Pollinators Beyond the Honey Bee 
 
         
  
  
    
 
 
     
  
 
 
  
  
       
 
For many crop species, honey 
bees are not effective pollinators! 
Crops including  tomato, pepper, 
blueberry require 
buzz 
pollination
, which cannot be 
carried out effectively by honey 
bees

Part I
: Managed Pollinators Beyond the Honey Bee 
Measure of pollination effectiveness 
  
 
 
    
 
         
      
  
  
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
  
  
 
  
 
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the
honey bee
These species 
can be more 
effective 
pollinators than 
honey bees
! 
Including carpenter 
bees (
Ceratina
), 
leafcutter bees 
(
Megachile
), stingless 
bees (
Tr i g o n a
) 
and 
even flies 
(
Eristalis
, 
other Diptera)! 
Obregon et al. (in prep)

Part I
: Managed Pollinators Beyond the Honey Bee 
  
 
 
    
 
         
             
  
              
             
 
   
 
            
   
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the
honey bee
•
 
In summary – there are a diversity of bee and fly taxa that can be 
managed for crop pollination services! 
•
 
However, when we talk about impact of managed pollinators on wild 
pollinators, nearly all the evidence comes from honey bees (
Apis 
spp.) 
and bumble bees (
Bombus 
spp.) 
•
 
Honey bees and bumble bees are by far the most important 
commercial pollinators on a 
global scale
Part II: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators

Part II: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
 
 
 
             
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
•
 
PE question : what do you think are the main ways managed 
pollinators could impact wild pollinators?

Pollen Theft! 
Attempt of a honeybee 
worker (
Apis 
mellifera
) to 
steal pollen from the 
abdominal scopa of a 
wood
-boring bee (
Lithurgus 
chrysurus
) 
Sauberer 
et al 2023

Part II: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
 
 
 
     
  
  
  
 
 
 
      
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
TWO KEY WAYS MANAGED BEES IMPACT WILD POLLINATORS 
(A) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
(B) 
Transmission of pathogens. 
Mallinger 
et al. 2017: 
https://
doi.org
/10.1371/journal.pone.0189268

Part IIA: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
  
 
    
 
  
       
  
    
                
  
  
 
 
 
 
  
      
 
 
 
      
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the
honey bee
(A) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
Managed bees can exclude other pollinator species from visiting shared 
flowers by monopolizing and depleting available resources 
(
exploitative competition
). 
Most of the evidence here comes from honey bees 
vs. 
wild pollinators. 
Mallinger 
et al. 2017: 
https://
doi.org
/10.1371/journal.pone.0189268

Part IIA: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
    
 
  
       
 
                     
   
         
       
           
   
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
(A) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
When honey bee foragers find a great flower patch, she will fly back to 
the hive and recruit her sisters to visit that patch via the waggle dance. 
This can result in a colony of honey bees competing with single bee 
foragers of other species.

Exploitative competition: resource use by one species prevents or 
reduces use by the other species 
Bumble bee diet 
Honey bee diet 
Slides by: Dr. Maureen Page 
Niche overlap

Part IIA: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
    
 
 
       
        
   
  
  
 
        
  
 
           
     
  
 
  
 
      
 
  
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
(1) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
A single honey bee hive extracts enough pollen in one month to rear 
33,000 native bees! 
There is clearly 
potential 
for honey bees to use up all the floral 
resources in a given site, forcing wild bees to make do with less – and 
maybe even result in population declines. 
But is there evidence this 
happens? 
Cane and Tepedino 2016
: 
https://doi
-
org.proxy.library.cornell.edu/10.1111/conl.12263

Part IIA: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
    
 
 
       
       
 
  
              
    
 
      
 
 
  
 
   
 
    
 
     
 
 
  
 
    
 
      
 
(fewer flowers = greater competition)
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
(1) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
Many studies do show that honey bees can reduce pollen and nectar 
availability for wild bees – but not always! 
About 
55% of all published studies on the topic show evidence 
of a negative effect of managed bees on wild bees via resource 
competition 
(Mallinger et al. 2017). 
Mallinger 
et al. 2017: 
https://
doi.org
/10.1371/journal.pone.0189268

Part IIA: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
    
 
 
       
      
 
 
   
 
 
  
     
  
  
   
 
           
 
     
       
     
 
      
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
(1) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
Why isn’t there a consistent response of managed bees on wild pollinators? 
Effect on wild pollinators likely depends on: 
•
 
The density of managed bees (
more bees = greater competition
) 
•
 
The proximity of a wild pollinator community to managed bees (
closer 
the managed bees = greater competition
). 
•
 
The amount of floral resources (
fewer flowers = greater 
competition
) 
Mallinger 
et al. 2017: 
https://
doi.org
/10.1371/journal.pone.0189268

Slides by: Dr. Maureen Page
For example, greater honey bee abundance decreases nectar and 
pollen availability in California wildflower meadows

And greater proximity to honey bee apiaries also decreases 
resource availability...

600m 
And greater proximity to honey bee apiaries also decreases 
resource availability... 
                  
 
 
  
  
   
  
 
  
 
  
Within 600m of 
apiaries, honey 
bees outcompete 
wild bees.Wild 
bees can collect 
little nectar. 
At distances 
>600m
, 
competition is 
“relaxed” 
Henry & 
Rodet
, 
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.actao.2020.103555

600-750m 
...and increased competition close to apiaries can lead to 
reduced reproductive success and potential population declines! 
 
  
  
   
  
 
  
 
  
  
  
 
  
 
      
 
  
  
  
 
Within 600m of 
apiaries, honey 
bees outcompete 
wild bees.Wild 
bees can collect 
little nectar. 
At distances 
>600m
, 
competition is 
“relaxed” 
Henry & 
Rodet
, 
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.actao.2020.103555 
Within 750m of 
apiaries, wild 
bumble bees 
produce fewer 
offspring. 
Thomson 2004, 
https://doi
-
org.proxy.library.cornell.edu/10.1890/02
-
0626

Part IIA: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
    
 
 
       
         
  
 
 
  
      
  
    
    
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
(A) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
Reduced resource availability as a result of direct competition with 
honey bees can decrease reproduction of wild bees
, 
but data is 
limited and more research is required 
to understand how these 
effects translate into overall population trends!

Part IIA: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
    
 
 
       
 
 
 
    
 
          
                   
  
     
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
(A) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
Key  take
-
aways 
•
 
Resource competition between managed bees and wild pollinators 
can have negative impacts on those wild bees, but not always! 
•
 
Several factors mediate whether managed bees will have a negative 
effect on wild pollinators via resource competition.

Part II: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
 
 
 
     
  
  
  
 
 
      
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
TWO KEY WAYS MANAGED BEES IMPACT WILD POLLINATORS 
(A) 
Direct competition for floral resources 
(B
) 
Tr a n s m i s s i o n   o f   p a t h o g e n s .  
Mallinger 
et al. 2017: 
https://
doi.org
/10.1371/journal.pone.0189268

Part IIB: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
    
 
          
       
  
  
 
        
   
     
  
 
  
  
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
(B) 
Tr a n s m i s s i o n   o f   p a t h o g e n s .  
Because both honey bees and bumble bees are social bees, the high 
density of bees living close together, often in stressful agricultural 
environments, facilitates pathogen transmission. 
Pathogen spillover 
= pathogens can build to high levels in managed 
bee colonies and can then be shared with wild bee communities where 
normally, pathogen incidence is much lower.
Part IIB: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators

Part IIB: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
  
 
 
    
  
 
    
 
  
    
   
  
    
  
 
   
   
 
 
  
 
        
   
 
 
 
      
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the
honey bee
(B) 
Tr a n s m i s s i o n   o f   p a t h o g e n s .  
Pathogen spillover from managed bees to wild pollinators has the 
greatest amount of empirical evidence. 
Of all published studies on 
the topic, the majority of 
studies (70%) reported negative 
effects of managed bees on wild bees via pathogen 
transmission. 
Mallinger 
et al. 2017: 
https://
doi.org
/10.1371/journal.pone.0189268

Part IIB: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
(B) 
Tr a n s m i s s i o n   o f   p a t h o g e n s .  
CASE STUDY 
Managed, non-native bumble bee 
Bombus 
terrestris 
was introduced to Chile in 1998; 
established self-sustaining populations and 
massively expanded their range. 
Led to dramatic, declines of native bumble bee 
Bombus 
dahlbomii 
Schmidt
-
Hempel 
et al. 
2014: 
https://doi.org/10.1111/1365
-
2656.12185 
Bombus 
dahlbomii 
  
 
 
    
 
  
 
    
 
    
     
 
   
   
  
 
 
 
    
 
  
 
 
Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee

Part IIB: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators 
(B) Transmission of pathogens. 
•
 
Within 10 years of introduction, 
Bombus 
dahlbomii 
(orange) 
disappeared from nearly all sites 
where non-native 
Bombus 
terrestris 
was present (yellow). 
•
 
Bombus 
dahlbomii 
is now listed as 
endangered by the 
IUCN Red List
. 
Schmidt
-
Hempel 
et al. 
2014: 
https://doi.org/10.1111/1365
-
2656.12185

dahlbomii

terrestris

terrestris

in 1998

: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators
(B) Transmission of pathogens.
•
Bombus 
dahlbomii
d
eclines likely due 
to parasites carried by 
Bombus 
terrestris
that had not been

before 
Bombus 
terrestris
’ 
introduction, but are now found in 
most wild 
Bombus

Schmidt
-

Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
Part IIB
: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators
(B) Transmission of pathogens.
Over a million bumble bee colonies are 
shipped from commercial suppliers each year, 
potentially spreading disease
•
In 2011, over 
75% of
Bombus 
terrestris
colonies 
purchased from three companies in the UK 
contained parasites
! 
Clear need for
stricter controls on 
international movement of bees 
and 
improved hygiene and parasite screening of 
colonies
(
Goulson
& Hughes 2015
)
Graystock
 
et al. 
2013, 
https://doi.org/10.1111/1365
-
2664.12134

Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
Part IIB
: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators
The logical solution here is to not transport 
managed pollinator species outside of their 
native range, eliminating risk of sharing 
pathogens with wild pollinators. 
But species like 
Apis
mellifera 
already have a 
global distribution, and are also well
-
documented to transmit pathogens to wild 
pollinators!

Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
Part III

–
 
Sustainable Beekeeping to Protect 
Wild Pollinators
How to mitigate risk of pathogen spillover from established managed 
bee species? 
My dissertation research addressed how 
beekeeping practices can influence the 
risk of pathogen spillover to wild 
pollinators, specifically looking at 
Varroa
 
mites and deformed wing virus (D!

Varroa cannot be shared from 
Apis
to other wild 
bee species, but the viruses they transmit can 
infect other bees! 
Evidence shows that viruses can spill over from 
managed honey bees to wild pollinators.
Deformed wing virus is the most cosmopolitan 
honey bee
-
associated virus 
-
found over 22 bee 
genera! 
(
Genersch
et al. 2006, 
Graystock
et al. 2016, 
Meeus
et al. 2014)

We found that three factors influenced 
whether we found DWV on flowers: 
Varroa infestation in the apiary
Honey bee density
Distance from the apiary

whether we found DWV on flowers: 
Greater apiary

flowers

honey bee

prevalence of DWV on flowers

more likely to have DWV
Matches the factors leading

competition!

Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the 
honey bee
Part IIB
: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators
(B
) Transmission of pathogens.
One final caveat...
•
There is a lot of evidence that managed bees can transmit pathogens 
to wild pollinators BUT 
not all pathogens may cause harmful 
infections in every bee species
. 
•
The risk of pathogen spillover will differ by pollinator species! 
•
DWV causes harmful effects in some, but not all bee species

Part I: Managed pollinators beyond the honey bee
Part IIB
: Impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators
(B
) Transmission of pathogens.
Key Takeaways
•
There is a lot of evidence showing that managed bees share 
pathogens with wild pollinators, which may have harmful impacts on 
wild pollinator health or population decline. 
•
Beekeeper management of pests & pathogens in honey bees not only 
impacts honey bee health but also has downstream impacts on wild 
pollinator community.

Key Take
-
away 
Managed bees can sometimes, but not always, have negative impacts 
on wild pollinators through resource competition and pathogen 
spillover.

Key Take
-
away 
So, how can these negative impact of managed 
bees on wild pollinators be mitigated?
Managed bees can sometimes, but not always, have negative impacts 
on wild pollinators through resource competition and pathogen 
spillover.

PE: Think of one of the three ways managed bees can negatively 
impact wild pollinators. What intervention(s) could reduce that 
impact? 
Part IV
:  S t r a t e g i e s   t o   m i t i g a t e   r i s k

We   n e e d   b o t h   m a n age d   b e e s   a n d   w i l d   b e e s !  
●
Managed pollinators are necessary for current intensive agriculture 
systems. 
Part IV
:  S t r a t e g i e s   t o   m i t i g a t e   r i s k
•
But even with managed honey bees 
present, wild pollinators still improve 
yields for many crop species!

(1) Plant native flowers and 
advocate for more flower 
plantings in your city!
The more floral resources available, 
the less intense competition 
Particularly
flowers that have abundant 
nectar/pollen resources. 
Many ”ornamental” species look 
pretty but don’t provide much for 
pollinators. 
Part IV
:  S t r a t e g i e s   t o   m i t i g a t e   r i s k

(2) Limit honey bee presence on 
conservation lands. 
●
Limit apiary size (fewer colonies = fewer bees)
●
Beekeepers 
should avoid placing 
apiaries less 600m 
from sensitive habitats or in areas that may support 
imperiled pollinator species. 
●
Beyond 600
-
750m of an apiary (“danger zone
”)
,
competition for flowers and DWV deposition on 
flowers decreases substantially. 
Strategies to mitigate risk
Rusty Patched Bumble Bee
600
-
750m
Adapted from Henry & 
Rodet
, 
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.actao.2020.103555

(3) Equip beekeepers to manage pests 
and pathogens effectively!
Varroa mite monitoring and control = safeguard 
both honey bees and wild pollinator community!
Discourage 
treatment
-
free beekeeping 
to
avoid untreated honey bees sharing viruses with 
wild pollinators.
V
Strategies to mitigate risk

(3) Equip beekeepers to manage pests 
and pathogens effectively!
Some states are requiring beekeepers to put 
together varroa management plan every year
Investing in extension programs can help 
beekeepers manage varroa 
–
NYS Beekeeper 
Tech Team
works alongside beekeepers to share 
best management practices 
V
Strategies to mitigate risk

(4) Integrate wild pollinator 
health into sustainable honey 
certification programs.
As we’re developing “sustainable” honey 
labels 
-
we should consider consumer 
health but also health of bee communities 
that might be affected by beekeeping 
activities. 
Strategies to mitigate risk

(5) 
Minimize transportation of 
non
-
native species and require 
pathogen testing for 
international commerce in 
managed pollinators.
Strategies to mitigate risk

To have healthy & productive agricultural & 
natural ecosystems, we need 
both 
managed bees and wild bees!
Although managed bees may have negative 
impacts on wild pollinators, many of these 
effects can be mitigated through improved 
policies and more sustainable management! 
Conclusions

END
Conclusions

Learning Objectives
: Managed vs. Wild Pollinators 
•
Explore diversity of managed pollinators beyond the 
honey bee
. 
•
Identify ways in which managed bees may 
negatively influence wild pollinators. 
•
Evaluate a case study of using sustainable 
beekeeping practices to protect wild 
pollinators. 
•
Explore strategies to mitigate negative 
impacts of managed bees on wild pollinators.
